And although recently her voice was taken from her by the cruel illness she fought so bravely, her kind and loving personality, her fun and spirited nature and her warmth still shone through and touched everyone who grew to know her, even the health care workers over the past  months.Mr Sloan is urging the public to continue to support hospices during as the lockdown.Mrs Sloan is also survived by Paddy, her husband of  years, daughter Roisin, son-in-law Michael, daughter-in-law Dearbhla, grandchildren Ethan, Chloe, Rioghnach, Hannah, Fiadh and Siacutene, sisters Geraldine and Elishand brothers Damien and Des.To support Marie Curie donate online at mariecurie.org.uk emergency or text NURSE to  to help us reach the families who need us. Texts cost pound plus  standard rate message.If you, or someone you know, are affected by a terminal illness, and concerned about coronavirus, call free    to the Marie Curie helpline. You can also find more information at mariecurie.org.uk coronavirus..prettyPhoto

title: Memories of racing at Tyrella in 1980s
story: ONE of the late point-to-point meetings to take place prior to the lockdown was the popular East Down meeting at Tyrella.With fans missing out on any form of horse racing at present, a look back at the East Downrsquos meeting on Saturday, March , , should be of interest to those that love and miss the sport.Acting stewards that day were Major W S Brownlow, Brian McNabb, Brian Fitzsimons and Frank Turley The honorary surgeons were Dr J Erwin, Mr Johnnie Boyd, Dr Welby Henry, Dr F Curran and Dr Jimmy Love.The first race of the day was the confined hunt race with six of the ten entries going to post, and the   winner proving to be the grey mare Lisgarvan, owned by Ballynoe builder John Turley and trained by Jenner Maxwell. The successful jockey was the late and sadly missed George Mernagh.Garryhinch, owned by Mrs Grace Dunlop, of Killinchy, and ridden by Colin McBratney, finished second ahead of James Kellyrsquos Levedece, ridden by R Andrews.Paul McMahony rode Joe Mageersquos Islandmore while Kieran McLoughlin was on Tom Newsamrsquos Charlie Waterloo and Raymond Martin was on Billy McCluskeyrsquos Red Peter.The second race, the Elanco Chase Qualier, went to Celtic Bay, owned, trained and ridden by Ards man Peter Mawhinney, from River Saint, owned, trained and ridden by Frankie Fitzsimons. Ronnie Dukersquos Lucky Gem was third.The third race of the day was the Rearsquos Emporium Open race that saw ten go to post. Victory went to Wilson Dennisonrsquos Let Him Go, ridden by Ivon Keeling, from John McCawleyrsquos Veteran Nightmaster with his son Denis in the saddle.Third past the judge, W H Montgomery, was Adam Turnerrsquos Garland VI, ridden by his son John, whose sister Margaret also rode in the race.She was on board Andy Pandy, which ran in the Grand National and was a long way clear before falling.The fourth race was the Abbey Lodge Hotel Maiden race and it had to be ided. The first ision was won by Harold Kirkrsquos Sir Owen, ridden by Tony Martin, with Fulleria second, ridden by Mike Todd, later the manager of Down Royal racecourse for many years. Vicar General and John Bryson were third.The winner of the second ision was Leonard Phillips Derryvore, ridden by his son, Michael, with Bonnety Bridge second, owned by Sara OrsquoHarersquos mother and ridden by George Mernagh. Third home the David Law-ridden Ballyhock. Harold Kerr now buys horses for Willie Mullins.Only three finished in the East Downshire Open Farmers race, victory going to The Attorney in the colours of Brian Hamilton, providing Jenner Maxwell with a double, John Sleater being the successful rider of this one. Second home was Comber owner Dorothy Murdochrsquos Castlewell, ridden by her husband Alex, with Master of Sands, owned and trained by Dromorersquos George Wilson, third and ridden by Raymond Martin.The final race on the card was the Maginn Bros  and  year old maiden and victory went to Tramps Dream, ridden by Comber electrician Millar OrsquoPrey, who also played cricket for North Down.Ballybentragh, in Wilson Dennisonrsquos silks, took second ahead of Ballygowan owner Vincent Murrayrsquos Mr Deeds, ridden by Paul McMahon. Sadly Millar passed away at an early age.Neville Ring was the noted race reader at the meeting. Advertisers in the race card included the Dunmore Hotel, Killyleagh, which had just been bought by Eric Johnston and Mervyn Boyce of Ballygowan, Daft Eddyrsquos at Sketrick Island, near Killinchy, OrsquoReillyrsquos Bar  Restaurant, Dromara, M J McKay Chemist, Ballynahinch, Downpatrick Farm Equipment Ltd, OrsquoHarersquos, Castlewellan, Ginesirsquos Cafe, Ballynahinch, J  J Rearsquos, Downpatrick, Stewartrsquos Motor Works, Downpatrick, Seaforde Inn, Kane of Comber, Slaney Inn, Raholp, William Laverty Butcher, Downpatrick, and T McGreevy Butcher, Downpatrick. Unlike these days there were no Southern owned or trained runners. In  race cards cost  pence mdash they are now pound or pound.The red and white striped colours worn by the rider of Bonnety Bridge, belonging Mrs J Ferris of Newry, were also by Mark OrsquoHare when he rode Honeysuckle, the unbeaten mare and recent Cheltenham winner, to win her maiden point-to-point. Mark is married to Mrs Ferrisrsquo daughter Sara, whose father, Don, had his only win on Bonnety Bridge at Tyrella..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle family joins the frontline during pandemic
story: A NEWCASTLE father ndash whose entire family of seven work in the NHS ndash has urged people to take care of their mental health during the coronavirus lockdown.Noel McDonald and Ann, his we of  years, are senior healthcare professionals working in mental health services in Belfast.Mr McDonald made the call as he spoke of his pride at the three youngest of his five children becoming mental health nurses during the health emergency.Aaron , Callumand Niamhwere in their final year at university when they were released early into frontline hospitals when the coronavirus pandemic hit.The couplersquos eldest son Daniel, who is , is a senior social worker in the Belfast Trust and another son, -year-old Ryan, works with childrenrsquos services as an agency healthcare support worker.Mr McDonald is an operations manager at the Shannon Clinic at Knockbracken Healthcare Park in Belfast while Mrs McDonald works as a professional nurse lead, also in the Belfast Trust. The couple have  years of experience between them.Mr McDonald is also chairman of Bryansford GAC and his children have all played for the club.He spoke of the importance of keeping physically fit and active to maintain mental health during the lockdown.ldquoAnn and I are immensely proud of all childrenrsquos achievements, especially at this challenging Covid- time, said Mr McDonald.ldquoWe never encouraged them to come into health care. They had to develop the interest themselves. But we are so delighted and so proud that they did follow in our footsteps.Aaron and Callum, were studying in the same class at Queenrsquos University Belfast and are now working at Lagan Valley Hospital, Lisburn, and Belfast City Hospital, respectively. Niamh, who works at Antrimrsquos Holywell Hospital, was studying at the Ulster University at Magee in Derry.Mr McDonald said: ldquoLike any newly qualied health professionals, they were initially worried about going into the frontline but the support and training they got from their universities has been amazing. Their ward manager and other Trust staff have been so supportive and helped them settle into their new roles.ldquoWhile we are immensely proud at the contribution all our children are making at the moment, our message is really about protecting your mental health and working at your own positive self-esteem and keeping up with your physical fitness in order to maintain your mental health. All of our lives have been focused around doing that, including the children.ldquoWorking in mental health can be very draining but Ann and I have so much job satisfaction over the years and enjoyed every minute of it helping people. We wish that for our children as well, said Mr McDonald.He further stressed that help was still available for anyone who was experiencing mental health problems.ldquoWe are very aware that during the lockdown people have not been getting out and about as normal. Those who need mental support could be taking alcohol, drugs or whatever during self-isolation.ldquoThe message that Irsquom trying to put out is for people who are suffering from mental health issues should still be seeking help, even under these circumstances. The health service has not stopped providing mental health services. Itrsquos still open and people should feel that they can access those services..prettyPhoto

title: Orange Order joins Black Institution to help health service
story: THE Orange Orderrsquos Castlewellan District No  has joined forces with the Royal Black District Chapter No  to assist the health service during the coronavirus pandmeic.Last week the Castlewellan District distributed a batch of hand sanitisers to local nurse Julie Ritchie, with the consignment handed over by district treasurer David Scott.The sanitisers will be used by members of the South Eastern Trustrsquos community childrenrsquos and adult nursing disability teams.Members of the Castlewellan District received a share of the Grand Orange Lodge of Irelandrsquos consignment of presonal protection equipment which has been shared across a number of areas.In addition, local Orange Order officials have been able to use their contacts to secure a small quantity of visors which were urgently needed by a local care home.Castlewellan District No  mdash which comprises lodges in Castlewellan, Newcastle, Bryansford, Maghera, Aughlisnafin, Ballywillwill and Dundrum mdash is concentrating its support efforts on locally based health care staff, including those who work in nursing and residential homes..prettyPhoto

title: Pipe laying work starts in Newcastle
story: WORK is underway in the heart of Newcastle on the latest phase of a mains gas pipe-laying scheme.The Recorder revealed last week that Phoenix Natural Gas has seized the opportunity to make the most of the coronavirus lockdown by bringing forward work on the scheme in the resort as part of its poundm investment programme across East Down.Work started last week at the Dundrum Road and Railway Street junctions with Main Street, with contractors switching attention to a stretch of road between the Railway Street junction and Castle Bridge, adjacent to Newcastle library, from this week.Next Monday, it is planned to lay a section of mains pipe between Castle Bridge and the Bryansford Road junction, while seven days later, contractors will be laying pipework along the Bryansford Road, between the Central Promenade and Shimna road junctions.This particular part of the scheme concludes with a pipe being laid between the Bryansford Road and Bryansford Avenue junctions at Shimna Road.Work in the town centre was scheduled to start towards the end of the year, but Phoenix officials have been working with the Department for Infrastructure to identy areas where pipe-laying could be brought forward in order to avoid further disruption to traders, visitors and residents.Phoenix says it understands that Covid- has had a signicant impact socially and economically across the region and hopes that by expediting its works in Newcastle, it can utilise the lockdown period to not only avoid further disruption later in the year, but enable more people to have access to fuel choice before the winter period.The works will involve one lane closure mdash rather than a full road closure mdash with traffic management plans also in place and Phoenix aiming to utilise underground drilling equipment where possible.In addition, the company insists that its work will not impact on Newcastlersquos granite paving which was part of the resortrsquos multi-million pound public realm scheme completed a number of years ago.A Phoenix spokeswoman added: ldquoThe safety of our people and communities is of paramount importance to us and this work has only been scheduled following robust risk assessment and the implementation of additional operational procedures, in line with government guidance.ldquoWe will continue to review the appropriateness of this activity on a daily basis to ensure that it remains the best solution for the local area.Confirmation that Phoenix Gas is carrying out the work in the heart of the resort when it is anticipated that there will be less traffic, has been welcomed by two local politicians, South Down MLA Colin McGrath and Mournes councillor Laura Devlin.Mr McGrath said he appreciates that for many, the ongoing roadworks across East Down ldquohas been a complicated time, but is pleased that the company is now able to carry out additional works in the Newcastle area, much earlier than planned.Cllr Devlin said that while many aspects of le are currently dficult for everyone, it is pleasing that Phoenix is starting work in Newcastle town centre and will ensure that only one lane is closed, with the work not affecting the granite footpaths in the town centre.The schedule of the Newcastle works is available at www.phoenixnaturalgas projects..prettyPhoto

title: Portaferry athlete takes lockdown in her stride
story: CIARA Mageeanrsquos Olympic ambitions may have been put on hold owing to coronavirus, but shersquos taking the lockdown in her stride mdash almost.The  year-old Portaferry runner, who is currently holed up in Manchester, says the current restrictions arenrsquot that far removed from her normal training regime.Even so, she says there are days when she does not want to run and she also misses her family and friends back at home.ldquoWersquore all struggling mdash therersquos days I donrsquot even want to go out and run now, and that the thing I have to do and the thingI always look forward to, she said.ldquoTherersquos days Irsquove cried and been like, lsquoWhat the hell is this rsquo Irsquove chatted to my team-mates about that and you justhave to find little methods ad mechanisms to try and help yourself.Last Thursday, Ciara was one of a number of leading sportsmen and women at the virtual launch of Sport NIrsquos Wellbeing Hub in response to the COVID- challengeThe hub provides instant access to helpful information, guidance and screening that is tailored specically to help care for wellbeing needs.It offers a range of innovative tools and resources, including guided self-assessment via lsquoChatbotrsquo, self-help programmes and digital intervention tools, a searchable five ways to wellbeingrsquo map and a wellbeing information library.Ciara said: ldquoOur mental health is so vital and right now is a challenging time for all of us.A full-time athlete and a member of Team New Balance, Ciara lives in Manchester in the same house with fellow athletes Jip Vastenburg and Adam Craig. Right now shersquos spending a lot more time inside the house than outside.ldquoThankfully my training hasnrsquot changed hugely, but wersquore in the house an awful lot more. The whole season has disappeared, which is very strange because wersquore training without any real focus.ldquoWersquore all watching the news and seeing whatrsquos happening the world over, and wersquore all far away from our families.ldquoLast week Jip lost her grandmother and she couldnrsquot get home for the funeral mdash she had to watch it over Skype.Ciara is worried about members of her own family. Her elder sister, Myra, is a registrar at a hospital in Belfast, her younger sister, Nuala, is a nursing student, younger brother Brendan has volunteered to work in the Nightingale hospital in London and her mother, Catherine, also works in the NHS, while an aunt is a pharmacist. She also misses her boyfriend, who she hasnrsquot seen in a month.Ciara, who won the m bronze medal at the  European Championships and bronze again at the European Indoor Championships last year, happens to be in the form of her le.She improved on her own Irish indoor m record in January and smashed her personal indoor best at m a month later.Training and events were geared towards the Tokyo Games this summer but the Olympics have been pushed back to  because of the coronavirus pandemic.ldquoIrsquom feeling in fantastic shape so itrsquos a little frustrating - we had the whole season planned out, she said.ldquoEven down to the training camps you were going to go on, down to the very day that I was going tointo the Olympic village and then the day that I would possibly leave the Olympic village.ldquoIt is quite tough because all of those plans are all scuppered, itrsquos all up in the air and we donrsquot know when wersquore going to be able to start racing.ldquoThe circuit doesnrsquot have a clue when theyrsquore going to be able to race - it depends on when countries allow more movement and, ultimately, does anybody know ldquoIrsquom not going to feel too sorry for myself because I know therersquos an awful lot of people out there that are in a much harder place than me.In a recent interview with RTE Ciara revealed something about how she is coping with the coronavirus restrictionsQ Whatrsquos the first thing you do in the morning A At the minute when I wake up Irsquove been giving my boyfriend a wee call to say good morning. Irsquom not quite sure when Irsquoll get to see him next as Irsquom in Manchester and he is in Dublin so itrsquos a nice way to start my day and always puts a smile on my face.Q Whatrsquos your favourite exercise A Oh I feel like I should say running, as I am an athlete, butI was to think of my favourite it would probably be a few things. I do miss playing a team sport so probably camogie, I absolutely loved dodge ball in school sothat was an option Irsquod pick that, and I do enjoy my gym workouts getting to lt weights.Q Is there one particular skill you practice every day A Running, every day! Running is a gross motor sport so fine skills arenrsquot really a part of my daily training, but I do work on dferent areas of my fitness every day. I have to work on things such as flexibility and fine muscle control every day to keep myself injury free. In the athlete house though we have been honing dferent skills while on lockdown, trying out dferent Tik Tok dances, press ups, and trying to get our eye in with the sling shot in the back garden!Q Netflix and chill or a nice evening jog A Both, usually we have an evening run, easy four miles... then we chill and watch a movie after dinner. We have had to mix training up a bit with the changes but in an ideal world we get both in.Q Name one book you want to read.A Irsquom making my way through a few Malcolm Gladwell books. I love coming away with new information and enjoy a book that challenges my thought process. Then when I need to flake out Irsquod pick something like A Man Called Ove. Soanyone could recommend books like this to me theyrsquod be on my ldquowant to read list.Q On a scale of  to , how good are your DIY skills A Ohhhh, Irsquom going to give myself an . -  here. My daddy is a joiner so I spent my le watching him make and fix things, and soon learned the names of tools and how to use them. I do know my limits though so I stay away from the plumbing... luckily in Portaferry my dad has a lot of friends who are alsotradesmen so they all help each other out.Q Have you a favourite pre-training meal to help you through a tough session A We usually train in the morning so I tend to eat an OTE DuoBar, the vanilla flavour in my favourite, and a cup of tea. When it come to racing in the evening, something easy to digest is usually what I go for... rice is always a winner.Q Name one movie you want to watch.A , I was planning on watching it in the cinema before the lockdown.Q Whatrsquos the best way to stave off boredom A Oh as a full-time athlete I feel Irsquove been preparing for lockdown for years. My le is basically train, eat, sleep. For me therersquos a few things I enjoy. I love chatting with my family, Irsquom usually on WhatsApp most of the day chatting or messaging and keeping in touch. I also love arts and crafts, Irsquoll be making postcards to post to my boyfriend and siblings to make them laugh, and currently my little cousin is teaching me the guitar via WhatsApp. She is a tough taskmaster, I have a lesson every Thursday and Monday and homework in between so that keeps me busy Q Have you any tips for training at home A Set yourself some goals that you can realistically achieve from home. We are allowed out for our daily exercise so you can get some cardio in outside, find a route that works for you and follow the guidelines. When it comes to working out inside, have fun. Find new alternatives, there are so many exercises we can do with body weight, or with stuff we have about the house so be creative and have a bit of craic. If you need any ideas check out social media, so many people are sharing home workouts. Give yourself a plan or schedule and try to stick to it. Being home means we can fall into the habit of sitting about and it can be hard to feel motivated. At the beginning of each week set out your plan for the week, what day, what time, and what exercise. Write it down and stick it somewhere you can see. Creating a routineduring these strange times means we can take back a little control.Q Name one documentary you want to see.A Anything with David Attenborough, I absolutely love animals and nature, and could listen to his voice all day.Q Have you discovered any new music or podcasts A My music taste is so ied but my wee sis and cousin Tara introduced me to Beoga and I absolutely love it. A lad from my hometown, Ryan McMullan also features in some of their songs, always a nice surprise hearing a weePortaferry accent as Irsquom listening.Q Is there one piece of housework you can no longer avoid A My own room! I actually enjoy housework, everywhere but my own bedroom. Irsquoll clean all day but canrsquot be bothered with my own mess!Q Favourite room of the house to spend time in A We are lucky that the Team NB Manchester athlete house is lovely and has lots of space so my favourite room ies depending in the time of day. In the morning my bedroom gets lovely light, it makes me smile sitting there chilling. Then when I want a bit of company the front room or kitchen is where we chill as a team and have the craic... andthe sun shines, which it does on the odd occasion over here, we have a lovely garden.Both Jip and Adam are enjoying learning how to puck about with my hurl..prettyPhoto

title: Recycling facilities to reopen
story: THE districtrsquos household recycling centres could reopen next week.Located in Downpatrick, Castlewellan and Ballynahinch, the centres closed at the end of March in line with the government directive to help reduce the spread of coronavirus.The Recorder understands that the sites will reopen, provided Newry, Mourne and Down Council can satisfy itself that the move can be managed safely and there is no risk to the public or frontline staff.Mid and East Antrim Council has already opened its recycling centres and Stormont environment minister Edwin Poots recently published guidelines aimed at paving the way for waste centres across the province to reopen.The reopening is expected to be discussed at todayrsquos virtual meeting between senior council officials and the leaders of the main political parties.Members of the local authorityrsquos senior management team are currently evaluating theenvironment ministerrsquos guidelines and developing a staff plan to allow the reopening to proceed in a safe way.In addition, officers are liaising with their recycling contractors, a number of whom have furloughed staff. The contractors are responsible for removing waste from all  council amenity sites, with early suggestions that it could take at least one week to ready themselves for reopening.With strict guidelines in relation to social distancing remaining in place, council officers are looking at the potential risks of reopening the sites and the required measures to mitigate them, with suggestions that ratepayers may have to book a slot to visit.Police and other statutory bodies, including the Department for Infrastructure, along with neighbouring councils, are also being consulted about reopening the sites.Council officers have suggested the recycling sites will open in a ldquophased manner and that certain restrictions will apply. Discussions with trade union officials are also planned.This Friday, the Northern Ireland Executive will review the current coronavirus regulations which could pave the way for the reopening of recycling centres not just in the local council area, but across Northern Ireland.Local councillors Willie Clarke and Billy Walker say Newry, Mourne and Down Council is right to carefully assess the guidelines published by Mr Poots and proceed with caution.They say the key importance is the safety of staff and residents, with the councillors suggesting that a visit to a civic amenity site would need to be classed as an ldquoessential journey under the current coronavirus legislation.Cllr Clarke says it is vital that the council approaches the reopening issue with caution, given that ldquocoronavirus is still rampant and people are dying.He continued: ldquoAny decision needs to be based on medical advice and direction from the Assembly.ldquoRecycling centres have not been classed as an essential service and people on their way to such a facility could end up getting stopped by police and issued with an enforcement ticket and sent home.ldquoThe council must ensure that all the Trsquos are crossed and the Irsquos dotted before the centres reopen. I understand there is a need across the community for this to happen, but my appeal to people is be patient for just a little longer.Cllr Clarke added: ldquoA phased approach to reopening the centres has been discussed by the party leaders. There is no point opening the centresthe contractors who remove the waste are not able to do so. A decision also has to be taken on what waste will be accepted at the sites in the short term.ldquoThe last thing we want is everyone landing at the sites, people getting out of their cars talking to one another and maybe not social distancing. People are still dying s a result of the virus and we must keep that in mind.Cllr Walker said that while many people have been cleaning their homes, garages and outhouses during the lockdown, the council needed to ensure that its civic amenity sites can reopen in what he described as a ldquosafe and proper manner.He added: ldquoWe need to manage the reopening process carefully and ensure there are not long queues of people waiting to use the centres, particularly in Downpatrick, Ballynahinch and Castlewellan, with tailbacks of cars spilling on to busy main roads.ldquoThe council does not want to put ratepayers at any risk and, in my view, is rightly proceeding with caution. It is not a simple case of opening the entrance gates and letting everyone in.A Newry, Mourne and Down Council spokesman confirmed that the decision to close the recycling centres is continually being reviewed in-line with government essential travel restrictions.ldquoThe council is currently reviewing this guidance and the implications it will present when it reopens the centres within the district, the spokesman continued.ldquoIf a decision is made to reopen the centres, residents will be informed via updates on the council website, social media channels and through local media outlets..prettyPhoto

title: Ryan bakes tasty treats for heroic postmen
story: SOME superheroes really donrsquot wear capes ndash they deliver the post.To honour the work of the often unseen heroes of the local postal service Ryan Bogues has delivered a hamper of his famous baked treats to the Royal Mailrsquos Downpatrick sorting office.The  year-old, who has Downrsquos Syndrome and lives in Teconnaught, has has to suspend his popular Ryanrsquos Cookie Box initiative, which he started over four years ago, because of the coronavirus lockdown.Ryan was praised by Prime Minister Boris Johnston last year for fundraising for several charities through his Cookie Box scheme where people donate money for his baked goods.Hersquos helped by his mother, Hazel, who explained a line in a recent speech from Taoiseach Leo Varadkar inspired them to think of local postal workers.ldquoMr Varadkar used the line lsquonot all superheroes wear capesrsquo and that struck a chord with us, she said.ldquoWe have had to close the Cookie box, but Ryan wanted to still help. We have an excellent postwoman and thought that the postal workers were among the very many key workers who were all working really hard to ensure that their service goes on as normal so we felt that they deserved a Ryanrsquos Cookie Box hamper.She added that Ryan bakes enough goods to donate two hampers per week since the lockdown and they have gone to nursing homes, pharmacists and hospitals as well.The hamper, which contained a range of buns, traybakes and lemon drizzle cake was well received by the  men and women who work at the sorting office at the Ballydugan Road Industrial Estate.Manager Donal Carabine received the hamper last week and said it helped lt everyonersquos spirits.ldquoEveryone at the delivery office has been working hard to both work in new ways to ensure everyonersquos safety at work while continuing with our service, said Mr Carabine.ldquoWe are delighted to have been recognised as being amongst key workers by Ryan and his mother and the baked goods are appreciated by all. We thank them for their generosity and I can assure them that the treats didnrsquot last too long.Mr Carabine said that the staff were coping with delivering items, mainly packages, and were as busy as they would be at Christmas mdash the busiest time of the year.ldquoI think the staff are coping admirably with the demand, as well as abiding by the two-metre social distancing rule in work. We have had to reorganise the office and stagger the earlier start times of some staff but they have all risen to the challenge.The Downpatrick office delivers throughout the wider Downpatrick area as far as Seaforde, Ardglass, Crossgar and Saintfield.Mr Carabine said: ldquoThe workers are more than holding their own in terms of maintaining deliveries and keeping themselves safe, although in some areas, due to the need to protect workers, the service is a bit later than usual..prettyPhoto

title: Saintfield’s Leah battling to raise cash for charity
story: A SAINTFIELD mum is throwing her weight behind a gruelling event to raise money for charity.Leah McCourt, a champion mixed martial arts fighter, is undergoing a test of strength and endurance challenge for Christian Aid, which is responding to the coronavirus crisis in some of the poorest countries in the world.Over five days, -year-old Leah will be attempt to complete , exercises carrying a weighted bag used by combat athletes to build strength.Starting on Monday, Leah will complete the daunting daily task of , squats and lunges while carrying on her shoulders the crescent-shaped lsquoBulgarian bagrsquo filled with  kilos of sand and wool. Each daily session is likely to take up to three hours to complete.Leah is a professional MMA fighter and earlier this year she headlined a prestigious event in DublinHer fundraiser is in response to Christian Aidrsquos appeal to people to raise money by taking part in sponsored stay-at-home challenges as part of Christian Aid Week which runs from May -.Examples include completing , star jumps in the living room, a half marathon in the back garden, or the equivalent of a mountain climb by walking up and down the stairs.Leah is urging others to follow her example. ldquoThe current crisis has left many people feeling helpless, she said.ldquoHowever, it is still possible to do something positive and help others during the lockdown.ldquoExercise is important for our physical and mental health, but it also lts your spirits knowing you are raising funds to support a good cause.As the pandemic passes its peak in the developed world, the aid agency hopes that Leahrsquos endorsement will raise funds vital to slowing the spread of the virus in developing countries where there are few,any, ventilators and ICU beds.Christian Aid Ireland Chief Executive Rosamond Bennett thanked Leah for her support.ldquoLeah is a true champion and I hope she inspires others to take up the challenge, she said.ldquoChristian Aid works in some of the poorest countries in the world, and coronavirus cases have been reported in every one of them. We know the impact the virus has had here but poor countries donrsquot have enough doctors and nurses and very few,any ventilators or ICU beds.ldquoPeople wonrsquot get the treatment they needthey do fall ill, so itrsquos vital we do all we can to help make sure people protect themselves from coronavirus and help prevent the spread of the disease.In order to carry out its work, the charity relies heavily on the donations it receives each during Christian Aid Week.The majority of these donations come from door-to-door and annual church service collections, neither of which is possible because of current restrictions.Christian Aid tackles the root causes of poverty around the world and is currently responding to the coronavirus crisis in nearly  countries by helping to raise awareness of the importance of regular hand washing and physical distancing to prevent the spread of the disease, as well as distributing soap and improving access to water.To support Leahrsquos sponsored stay-at-home challenge, visit her Justgiving page at https:www.justgiving fundraising christianaid-leah-mccourt.To sign up for Christian Aidrsquos Active Aid campaign, visit www.caid.ie activeaid..prettyPhoto

title: Sisters caring for abandoned lambs
story: A SMALL flock of orphaned lambs have found a new home thanks to three sisters from Clough.The pet lambs, which are less than a month old, were abandoned by their mothers, but are now in the loving care of the Ashe sisters mdash  year-old Charlotte, eight year-old Ruby and Eliza, who is six.The lambs, named Lucky, Spud, Tommy, Shaun, Buttercup and Maggie, are too young to be put out to pasture and are being bottle-fed four times a day.Their new home is a field off the Claragh Road, they have comfy straw beds to sleep on and their new playmates are three young girls who canrsquot believe their luck.The girls are currently off school because of the lockdown and looking after the lambs is a fantastic way to spend their time between when theyrsquore not doing homework and helping with chores at home.Their mum, Cara, said: ldquoThe girls are loving every minute of it. At the moment theyrsquore basically living their lives around the lambs.ldquoAs soon as they wake up they go up to the field and give the lambs their first bottles of the day. Then they go home, have their own breakfast and do some homework. Around am they go back to see the lambs. After that itrsquos lunch, more homework and dinnertime for the lambs.ldquoThe girls keep the lambs in a field beside their grandad Erniersquos house. They play in the field most of the day and are kept in a secure pen at night.Each lamb has its own personality and they start bleating when they hear the girlsrsquo voices. They canrsquot wait to get to them.The girls are also learning quickly about what is required to keep livestock. They have a log book in which they record their weight and how much they eat.Adds Cara: ldquoCharlotte would like to become a vet and this is a great experience for her. In fact, all the girls are learning a lot and they would like to thank farmers who gave the lambs for providing them with this experience..prettyPhoto

title: There’s great work being done by the Irish in New York
story: A FORMER Ardglass man now living in New York has revealed how the Irish community have been coming together to support each other during the Covid- pandemic.Tommy McConvey was hoping to travel back home to celebrate his th birthday among his family and neighbours in Curranrsquos Bar in Chapeltown later this month. He is disappointed at having to postpone his trip, but says itrsquos better to remain in New York.Tommy, who is a treasurer of a global finance company, usually commutes by subway into the heart of the Big Apple each day. However, since the city went into lockdown on March , Tommy has been self-isolating at home with his girlfriend, Lia.The former Crew Road resident has been living in New York since ,after he completed his Masters degree at Queenrsquos University Belfast, and says he only intended staying for six weeks.That same year he flew to Dublin on September  mdash the same day as the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center, which he and friends had visited the previous day.ldquoWe had taken pictures with the security guards and other workers and it still haunts me wonderingthose guys were able to make it out alive, he says.Tommy says that  years on fear has ed to the streets of New York.ldquoAt the beginning of the pandemic back in early March our company was swt to respond. We put social distancing measures in place and rotated staff on a sht basis so that only a third of workers were in the office each day.ldquoWe knew the virus was going to get more severe so after we learned the St Patrickrsquos Day parade was to be cancelled we took that as a signal and mandated that all staff should stay at home.Tommy says the sweeping changes have left an eerie feeling in their wake.ldquoIn the first few weeks the only workers that remained in the city centre were builders availing of free movement and the empty streets to get ahead with development projects, but they too were forced to quit, he said.ldquoTraffic has all but ceased, apart from a few ambulances and delivery trucks.ldquoThe economic impact of coronavirus has been devastating, particularly for the Irish who have found themselves furloughed off, out of work and not entitled to any government aid.ldquoA charity has been set up called Slainte  which was formed with the sole intention of alleviating the suffering that many have been going through and to help those less fortunate to get through it.Tommy is also a leading figure in the GAA in New York which is supporting Slainte .At the weekend local Gaelic footballers in the city ran a combined distance of , kilometres, which is the equivalent of running theof Ireland, from Malin Head in Donegal to Mizzen Head in Cork mdash and back.The event was in place of a cancelled Gaelic football tournament and all proceeds went to Slainte .ldquoOver half of the people who have applied for help from Slainte  are in the hospitality industry which looks to be one of the last groups that willto work in all likelihood.ldquoThere is also a lot of great work being done by other Irish community groups in New York.Tommy says it is very encouraging to see the Irish community pull together during a time like this.He said: ldquoThe Irish are renowned for putting their shoulder to the wheel in times of adversity and the last few weeks have been no dferent.ldquoWersquore looking after each other as we always have done when hardship strikes.Tommy says people can still make donations to Slainte  by going to the link www.slainte.org..prettyPhoto

title: line up of calves win over judges at calf fair
story: Breed judges from throughout the UK and Ireland were unanimous in their praise for the Pedigree Calf Fair and Beef NI Expo, held at the Balmoral Showgrounds in Belfast on SaturdaySpeaking after the one-day show, which featured three show rings and  native and continental beef breeds, event organiser and Chairman, David Connolly said: ldquoItrsquos been another fantastic event, and we certainly exceeded our strap-line lsquoBigger and Betterrsquo.ldquoThe  show has surpassed last yearrsquos inaugural event, attracting hundreds of spectators and more than  trade exhibits. Cattle entries were on a par with last year, and the judges were all impressed with the quality of the calves and the high level of stockmanship.ldquoOur judges have been busy throughout the day, and all were in agreement that the show provides a  for the provincersquos pedigree beef champions of tomorrow. Many of last yearrsquos winners went on to achieve top accolades and command high prices at local and national shows and sales. I have no doubt that many of this yearrsquos prize winners will follow in their footsteps.David Connolly continued: ldquoOne of the highlights of the day was seeing  of the countryrsquos best calves enter the show ring for the grand parade. This was a spectacular sight to round-off another successful show. Shows are a shop window for our pedigree livestock.Full results and photos of the Calf Fair in next weekrsquos Impartial Reporter.and the success of the event confirms that there is a need for a multi-breed beef show at this time of year. ldquoFrench judge Laurent Antignac was impressed with the professionalism of the young showmanship competitors. ldquoThey are a credit to Northern Ireland, he commented.While many eyes were firmly fixed on the ious breed classes, the overarching theme for the event was Beef Strategy . Several keynote speakers took to the stage to deliver short presentations aimed at helping farmers to encompass the breeding, nutrition and health needs of the industry.The seminar sessions included short presentations by Dr Francis Lively, AFBI William Minchin, MSD Animal Health and Paul Elwood, HVS Animal Health. title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. title: we need proper public debate about whether harm covid  justifies cost lockdown and closing down entire economy
story: Ballycastle tragedy: Mum Clare and daughter Bethany attended Bush Tots group - Presbyterian Church urges people to pray for other daughter Hannah still in hospitalDevastation after mother and young daughter killed in collision between quad and tractor near their homeNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensCoronavirusFarmingNewsOpinionWe need a proper public debate about whether the harm of Covid- justies the cost of lockdown and closing down an entire economyTruth be told, I am quite enjoying the current lockdown, but then I mostly work from home anyway.By James DingleyWednesday, th May , : pmUpdated Wednesday, th May , : pm""There is public appreciation on a Thursday evening for NHS workers but when the emergency is over how many will vote for higher taxes to fund better services  : GuzelianBut what I really appreciate is how calm and peaceful it is outside, especially with the sun shining, almost no traffic and few people on the streets. That said, I am also lucky in having a very nice home, with a good garden in a leafy suburb and a steady work pension. However, spare a thought for those not so lucky and with no garden or nice leafy suburb, also those not feeling secure in ing to a job or restarting a business once we are unlocked.Dr James Dingley is a Belfast based academic and chair of the Francis Hutcheson Institute : Other rd Party " fill"#ea" to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This latter is an increasingly serious point since there is a growing tendency to see unlocking in terms of an economy versus health choice. The two are irretrievably entwined.First, lost jobs and businesses do cost lives, not dramatically in a sudden endemic. It kills just as surely over a period of time and also eats up expensive health, social and welfare services that we may need to help fend off the next pandemic. Second, the economy is what pays for our health, social and welfare services. Poor economy means fewer resources both in terms of increased demand for those services whilst concurrently implying a lower tax yield and hence lower income stream for those services we are now so appreciative of. Of course it must be gratying for those concerned to see all the public appreciation, on a Thursday evening, for their services. However, I cannot help wondering just how long this will last after the emergency is over. How many will vote for higher taxes to pay for better services, especially social welfare which takes such a burden off the NHS  How many tax dodgers in off-shore funds will volunteer to repatriate their billions to pay tax on it to maintain the NHS  What effort by our politicians and civil servants to clean up their act and ensure no more RHI scandals so that the money saved can go into better care and health facilities. Fewer £,pa Spads and more nurses or bio-medical scientists might be a good start, then we would also need fewer multi-million pound inquiries. Quiz our politicians, now that they are back, on that one.Meanwhile, we still have to deal with the current pandemic, and here I wish to raise a, not unrelated, serious question: just how serious is the current pandemic  I am not trying to trivialise, but deaths happen all the time, it’s normal.Thus the question arises of: how big an increase in deaths over the normal rate is currently occurring  Here one has to turn to the statistics, which are always dficult to analyse adequately, hence imperfect, but all that the decision takers have to go on.Working from the Office of National Statistics for England and Wales, week ending th March,  : .%deaths in the over  bracket involved Covid-: in - bracket it was .% : meanwhile no Covid- deaths were recorded in the under one and - age groups. Meanwhile, the total number of Covid- deaths was , out of a total of , deaths , thus  Covid- deathswere in the age group +. Meanwhile, .% of all deaths mentioned ‘influenza or pneumonia’ , Covid- or both. By comparison, the previous five year average for deaths involving influenza and pneumonia was .%.The foregoing is just an example of the kind of figures decision makers will have to grapple with. First this seems to be a virus that particularly affects the elderly and those with underlying respiratory conditions. When placing Covid- related deaths in perspective, the majority appear to affect those who have already reached, or nearly, the modern average le expectancy . More recent data since that cited above confirms that the median age of people who die is over .Is it just that a new disease is carrying us off rather than an old one If that is the case, then what is the justication for closing down an entire economy, which will also involve many premature deaths, perhaps of much younger and potentially more productive people.This is not an easy or comfortable question, and I am not proposing any answer, but it is one that needs asking and should be the basis for proper public debate, both in the media and politically.As the News Letter editorial ‘The world’s oldest daily newspaper is reporting this pandemic as it has reported other global health crises over the centuries,’ April  reminds us, in  , died from plague in Constantinople – that would cause panic, but we should not. Covid- is serious, but just how much in the great scheme of things has yet to be fully appraised and we need to keep calm and, especially, think rationally of how and where we limit the worst effects.• Dr James Dingley is chairman of Francis Hutcheson Institute

title: cardiff south penarth mp stephen doughty calls keir starmers labour leadership win ray hope difficult times
story: The MP for Holborn and St Pancras defeated Lisa Nandy and Rebecca Long-Baily.Mr Doughty has previously expressed his support for Sir Keir, who won on the first round of voting with . per cent of ballots cast.Stephen called Sir Keirs ascension a ray of hope, and said that the party should now turn its attention to winning elections.He said: ldquoI am so pleased that Keir Starmer has become UK Labour leader.ldquoThe ray of hope Keir represents could not come at a more critical time.ldquoHis message of unity has won over members up and down the country ndash and we need to ensure that we model that through the whole of the UK Labour Party.ldquoAnd it is clear that Labour comes out of this contest stronger, with Rebecca and Lisa running really positive campaigns.ldquoThe UK General Election result in December was devastating for Labour and we cannot repeat it."Thatrsquos why Keirrsquos campaign was all about focussing the party on winning elections. Only then can we change peoplersquos lives."Welsh Labour, and First Minister Mark Drakeford will now be working closely with Keir to ensure we win the Senedd elections next year.ldquoKeir has already shown his commitment to Wales and Welsh Labour, and personally visited Cardf South and Penarth with me just a few months ago to meet local residents.ldquoWe also need to restore peoplersquos trust in the Labour Party as a force for good - a crucial part of that is tackling antisemitism."I know that Keir has the values, vision and moral compass needed to fight for justice at home and abroad ndash and that is needed more than ever.ldquoNobody could have predicted the campaign ending in these hugely dficult circumstances - and regardless of the result, our primary thoughts at the moment are with all those affected by coronavirus, and our brilliant NHS and social care staff, and key workers up and down the country who are keeping us going and saving lives every day."The Labour Partyrsquos number one priority right now is working across party lines to help the country get through this.ldquoI am also delighted Angela Rayner has been elected our new UK Deputy Leader ndash someone who I have campaigned with on a range of issues over many years. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentsOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... Only then can we change peoplersquos lives."Welsh Labour, and First Minister Mark Drakeford will now be working closely with Keir to ensure we win the Senedd elections next year.ldquoKeir has already shown his commitment to Wales and Welsh Labour, and personally visited Cardf South and Penarth with me just a few months ago to meet local residents.ldquoWe also need to restore peoplersquos trust in the Labour Party as a force for good - a crucial part of that is tackling antisemitism."I know that Keir has the values, vision and moral compass needed to fight for justice at home and abroad ndash and that is needed more than ever.ldquoNobody could have predicted the campaign ending in these hugely dficult circumstances - and regardless of the result, our primary thoughts at the moment are with all those affected by coronavirus, and our brilliant NHS and social care staff, and key workers up and down the country who are keeping us going and saving lives every day."The Labour Partyrsquos number one priority right now is working across party lines to help the country get through this.ldquoI am also delighted Angela Rayner has been elected our new UK Deputy Leader ndash someone who I have campaigned with on a range of issues over many years. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentsOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... title: virus decimated marie curie hospice charity income penarth
story: End of le patients who do not want to be in hospital need to be moved to a more appropriate setting, as beds in critical care units are urgently required for patients who need lesaving treatment.The charity, which relies upon public donations and fundraising events needs to raise pound million a year to continue to run its essential frontline services across Wales.However, chief executive Matthew Reed has said the charityrsquos income has been lsquodecimatedrsquo due to the outbreak.Rachel Moses-Lloyd from Marie Curie in Wales said: ldquoWhen the NHS and public need us most, we are facing huge dficulties raising our vital funds."Along with the cancellation of hundreds of high street and supermarket collections, wersquore now losing income from the closure of our charity shops and from cancelled fundraising events."The Marie Curie Cardf and the Vale Hospice in Penarth cares for around , people each year.Its manager, Sarah Lloyd-Davies, said: ldquoAcross Marie Curie we have provided care to a few terminally ill patients who have tested positive for coronavirus or are suspected of having it and do expect this to continue in future. For reasons of patient confidentiality we are not able to discuss specic cases of care from the hospice or from the community nursing care we provide.ldquoOur hospice staff and nursing teams across Cardf and the Vale are very much on the frontline and have an important job in keeping patients out of hospital to relieve pressure on the NHS. That is important now more than ever given the coronavirus crisis. The health and wellbeing of our patients, their loved ones, and our staff is our top priority and across the hospice and community we are taking steps to protect them. This includes the use of PPE and, in-line with other providers of care, including the NHS, we have amended our visiting rules at the hospice.ldquoWith regards PPE, unfortunately, our hospice and community nursing service have been facing the same issues as the NHS in terms of getting all the equipment they need. We are screening patients with a phone call before attending their homes and staff will wear the appropriate PPE equipment during every household visit. However, we can only do this when we have the right PPE equipment available and are grateful to have recently received support from our colleagues at the Cardf and the Vale University Health Board to gain access to some PPE through their supply, for which we give our thanks.ldquoHowever we are always in need of more supplies to continue to provide vital end of le care to people living with a terminal illness, especially at this dficult time. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: coronavirus  cases vale glamorgan lock extended
story: A total of  of these cases were in the Vale of Glamorgan where a further  people tested positive on Wednesday.In total  people have been tested for the virus in the Vale, of whom . per cent have tested positive.Meanwhile, the virus has claimed  more lives across Wales, meaning  have now passed away with the disease.There were  new cases of covid- reported in Wales, taking the total number of confirmed cases to ,, although the true number of cases is likely to be higher.Dr Robin Howe, Incident Director for the Novel Coronavirusoutbreak response at Public Health Wales, said: ldquoWe offer our condolences to families and friends affected, and we ask those reporting on the situation to respect patient confidentiality.ldquoPublic Health Wales has conducted more than , tests for Novel Coronaviruson more than , iniduals since the start of this outbreak.It comes as a Welsh Government minister said lockdown rules will continue into at least next week.When the UK-wide lockdown rules were announced, prime minister Boris Johnson said they would be reviewed every three weeks.Next Monday, April , marks three weeks since the announcement.But, speaking at a press conference yesterday, the Welsh Government housing and local government minister Julie James said this was too soon to lt the lockdown and the rules would remain in force in Wales into the start of next week - and possibly further.A more formal announcement on the continuation of lockdown guidelines will be given soon."These are extraordinary times, and weve taken these measures because by working together we can slow the speed of the coronavirus," Mrs James said."We will definitely be extending the guidelines, and more formal restrictions will be announced within the next few days. What I do know is that the measures will definitely stay in force after Monday."With the Easter weekend coming up, Mrs James also reiterated the importance of abiding by the rules."There are signs that these measures are having an impact," she said. title: food vouchers sent   parents vale glamorgan
story: Though schools in the Vale have been closed for normal lessons since Monday March , many continued providing free meals.But it was later discovered that only a small faction of these were being claimed.Now the parents of the  Vale pupils in receipt of free school meals have been sent vouchers, which can be used to purchase food from a local supermarket.Arrangements were put in place for Tesco and Asda vouchers to be distributed and it is hoped a similar system can be established with other food outlets, including smaller operators located in the rural Vale.Parents will receive a pound voucher every fortnight, which equates to  school meals worth pound. for each eligible child.Councillor Lis Burnett, Vale of Glamorgan Council Cabinet Member for Regeneration and Education, said: ldquoI have been immensely proud of the way council staff have responded to such dficult circumstances and there is no better example of that than within our Learning and Skills teams.ldquoIn just two days staff working there have established a completely new system for administering free school meal provision so that no child goes without.ldquoSetting up this voucher system will help ensure a great many more children get the meals they are entitled to as only a small proportion were recently being claimed from schools.ldquoThe need to develop this system so quickly inevitably means there will be some fine tuning along the way.ldquoWith that in mind, I would ask parents to let us knowthey experience any glitches in the system and thank them for their patience and title: cardiff south penarth mp stephen doughty calls international cooperation tackle coronavirus new labour frontbench role
story: The MP for Cardf South and Penarth will work alongside the Shadow Foreign Secretary, Lisa Nandy, as a joint Shadow Foreign Office and International Development Minister for the African continent.He was previously appointed as Shadow Minister for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs until he resigned from the position in .During his live daily Q and A session yesterday, Mr Doughty said: "I got a call from the Sir Kier Starmer yesterday letting me know hed like me to be a Shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs and International Development."Ill be working in two dferent teams with Lisa Nandy and Preet Kaur Gill - both fantastic people and Im delighted to be working with them."And the full front bench team was announced today so it will be a delight to go back and be in a shadow ministerial role."Its something that I feel Ive got a lot to contribute on but also is going to be so crucial because were seeing the impacts that coronavirus is having in this country with a developed health system with relatively strong levels of support for people, though I appreciate at the moment its incredibly dficult for people but compared to some countries around the world who literally dont have any of the type of equipment or expertise or staffing that we do in our health service."Im really fearful of some of the impact that will have in some of the poorest countries around the world, so this is undoubtedly going to be a big issue over the next few months and Im going to be working very closely with Kiers team to make sure we get the right support from governments across the world working together because were not going to solve this crisis by putting up barriers."Sir Keir won the Labour leadership contest in the first round of voting at a ballot last week, where he competed against Lisa Nandy and Rebecca Long-Baily.Mr Doughty has previously expressed his support for Sir Keir and called his victory a ray of hope. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: cafe offers delivery service help need
story: Staff at the Marie Curie Hospice in Penarth" Café offers delivery service to help those in needCharlotte Court , co-owner of Willmore#s , delivers food parcels ltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtto Llandough lt spangtlt spangt" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentA LOCAL cafeacute has started a regular food delivery service to support frontline staff and their patients who are suffering from Covid- at Llandough Hospital.The co-owners of Willmorersquos  on Stanwell Road, Matthew Holland and Charlotte Court, have delivered over  meals to frontline facilities in Penarth since the beginning of the pandemic, including the Marie Curie Hospice on Bridgeman Road.Now the pair have plans to extend their operations.They have raised over pound for the charitable cause, which includes money collected in a fundraiser by the community support group, Helping Hands Penarth.ldquoWe closed the shop three weeks ago and used all the leftover stock to do the first delivery to the hospital, explained Matthew.ldquoWersquove all got to be doing something and we felt like we had to utilize the shop and give something back to the guys that are putting their lives at risk.ldquoPenarth is a really small town and yoursquove just got to try and support each other as much as possible.ldquoI think yoursquove got to step up and do as much as you can,you can. Wersquove got the capacity to do it.Matthew went on to describe the atmosphere at Llandough Hospital.ldquoWersquore both in Penarth and wersquove lived here all our lives. Its important to us that we support it as much as possible.ldquoIts uplting being able to do that. It was so emotional being able to see the nurses on the Covid ward.ldquoFor me and Charlotte it was very humbling because those guys are putting their lives at risk and theyrsquore asking for stuff for patients, not for themselves.ldquoWe were quite tearful because we didnrsquot want to leave them there ndash but theyrsquore doing it day in-day out without batting an eyelid. Amazing people.Alongside their charitable work, Matthew and Charlotte have adapted to the challenging economic climate by introducing a delivery service for their customers.The pair have been working without the support of their staff who they had to furlough after the government closed all non-essential shops.ldquoWersquove started doing take-out because we canrsquot afford to do nothing for three months. Wersquoll lose the shop, said Matthew.ldquoWersquoll continue to do these drop offs for the hospital as long as people fund it, and wersquoll continue to do our take-out service.ldquoBecause for shops and restaurants I think its going to be long term.ldquoWe might be in this for six months before we can open to the public.ldquoAs long as we get the support and people keep shopping locally, then yes we can get through it.ldquoRunning a business is a constant challenge and you donrsquot ever stop having to adapt. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: view westminster stephen doughty mp
story: Irsquove also recorded online conversations with council leaders and police, and these are available to view on my page at any time. With lockdown and social distancing, itrsquos crucial that we keep residents informed, and modern technology allows us to do that.One of those conversations was with Cllr Lis Burnett, Deputy Leader of the Vale Council. I raised some of the most common questions that Irsquom receiving from constituents, to find out how the authority is supporting residents, including:School provision: The Vale is using a hub system, with  schools providing services am-to-pm, seven days a week, for children of key workers and vulnerable children. Vouchers for free school meals are being issued to all who qualy every two weeks.Older shielding residents: For those without support from family and friends, the council has set up a Crisis Support Team to help with access to shopping, medication, and urgent temporary assistance. See the lsquoProtecting Vulnerable Peoplersquo section of the dedicated coronavirus page on the website www.valeofglamorgan.gov.ukBusinesses: There is a regularly-updated Business section on the councilrsquos coronavirus page, which should be the first point of call for all local businesses looking for assistance. Over pound million has already been distributed, and yoursquore encouraged to apply for support as soon as possible.Council staff: Staff are helping however they can some from non-essential services are doing waste collections, others are providing care. Itrsquos making a huge dference, and a recruitment drive for temporary care staff has also been a success.Volunteering: Local people are stepping up, and the Vale is supporting them via its Vale Heroes page on the website.Council tax bills: If you are worried about paying your council tax, get in touch with the department. title: strategy announced lead wales lockdown
story: The framework will help to determine when the strict stay-at-home restrictions can begin to be relaxed in Wales and will help to find a way for people in Wales to live and work alongside coronavirus.A Wales-wide programme of surveillance, case identication, and contract tracing is being developed through the office of the Chief Medical Officer, Dr Frank Atherton. This will highlight the importance of community testing and support the containment of emerging coronavirus infections as and when restrictions are eased.Launching the framework, the First Minister said: ldquoOur approach to date has been one of lockdown. We have taken unprecedented steps to protect everyone, but particularly those most at risk from serious illness.ldquoThis has helped the NHS prepare and cope with coronavirus and, even though we have sadly seen more than  people die, it has helped to save many more lives. But this strategy comes with its own costs to peoplersquos wider health and wellbeing and long-term costs to our economy.ldquoWe are keeping these regulations under constant review. We know coronavirus will be with us for a long time yet but we want to see whether there are things we can do while we continue to tackle the virus and while the search for better treatments and a vaccine continue.The framework ndash and the seven questions ndash will help determine when the time is right to relax some of the stay-at home regulations.The seven questions are:bull Would easing a restriction have a negative effect on containing the virus bull Does a particular measure pose a low risk of further infection bull How can it be monitored and enforced bull Can it be reversed quicklyit creates unintended consequences bull Does it have a positive economic benefit bull Does it have a positive impact on peoplersquos wellbeing bull Does it have a positive impact on equality The Chief Medical Officer for Walesrsquo office has developed the Wales-wide programme of surveillance, case identication, and contract tracing.It will have four main strands ndash improved surveillance of cases of coronavirus effective identication of cases and contact tracing learning from international experience and engaging with the public.Dr Atherton said: ldquoAction to ease the lockdown restrictions will need to be supported by a comprehensive public health response, which will need to developed quickly and at scale.ldquoAcross the UK, we have worked and put in place unprecedented measures to contain and delay the spread of coronavirus. We have also worked to reduce the overall impact of the virus by strengthening essential services, including healthcare.ldquoWe are now working towards a new recovery phase to lead us out of the pandemic but only when the conditions are right.The First Minister added: ldquoCoronavirus is not going to disappear ndash it is likely it will be with us for a long time. We will need to have some sort of restrictions in place for some time yet to continue to control the spread of the virus and reduce community transmission. This framework will help us determine what is right for Wales.ldquoThere is a long road ahead of us towards recovery to pre-pandemic levels, butwe continue to work together, I hope we will be able to make changes to the restrictions and see a gradualto something resembling normal le.The Welsh Government has worked closely with the rest of the UK throughout the pandemic and has shared the development of the framework with the Scottish, Northern Irish and the UK governments. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... Plus by joining the Virtual Crafternoon and making a recommended donation of just £, you’re helping Hospice continue to provide their vital services to local people in your community living with le-limiting or le-threatening illnesses. What do you need Some water based felt tips to create your beautul rainbowAn A page, printer paper, A card and some scrap A sized card, paper towel Stamps, ink or an alcohol based black markerA water sprayer, glue, jewels, stickers and some of your favourite sequins to glitz your masterpiece upTo register visit https:bit.ly yAv. title: terex to re open omagh factory
story: Terex will resume production at a reduced capacity at all their sites in Northern Ireland, including in Omagh, from Monday, May .The decision was taken in compliance with local mandates and in response to customer demand and need, the company said.Where team members can work from home we are continuing to facilitate this, a spokesperson comment.This decision follows the Department for the Economy’s recent publication permitting a list of priority business sectors, which includes Terex, to continue to operate during the COVID- in the UK.Our primary focus during the COVID- pandemic is to ensure that we look after the health, safety and well-being of our workforce, and to do all that we reasonably can to protect our team members while at work.Our employees’ health and well-being is at the centre of our operations, and in order to keep our ing employees and workplace safe from the virus we have implemented comprehensive safety measures in line with Government guidance and Terex best practice.In particular we have conducted risk assessments and are following the guidance as set out in the Northern Ireland Practical Guide to making workplaces Safer’.Going forward, in addition to our other COVID- safety and preventive measures, we are introducing three compulsory enhanced measures to help protect the health and safety of team members and others who may need to come to our sites:. Health Checks Upon Entrance: COVID- health check self-assessment utilising the Health and Social Care Application and no-touch temperature screening checks to screen for high temperatures and avoid having sick persons on our site. Face coverings will be mandatory for close working and or face to face conversations. Social distancing measures across the sitesThese measures also extend to visitors to sites, and visitors will be on an essential basis only.By taking a series of actions we can reduce risk and improve our confidence that we can operate in a safe work environment. We anticipate that these measures will be in place for the foreseeable future.Our Leadership team will continue to monitor the situation daily.
